title: 110_hr5513
content: The Act titled "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" aims to strengthen state laws regarding tobacco product sales to individuals under the age of 18. The Act "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" requires states to have laws prohibiting the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18 years of age in order to qualify for grants. It is illegal for individuals under 18 years of age to purchase, receive, or possess tobacco products in public places. Law enforcement agencies must take action if a minor is found to have obtained or held tobacco products. Individuals under 18 found with tobacco products in public places must notify their parent or guardian. Retailers must inform employees distributing tobacco products within 180 days of the state law taking effect. Employers must notify employees about state laws prohibiting tobacco sales to individuals under 18 and ensure compliance. Employers can avoid violating age prohibition laws by relying on valid age proof or implementing an approved program. Individuals who break the law may face fines and community service. Some states have delayed enforcement of these regulations. The requirement for states to comply with age prohibition laws for grants under section 1921 may be delayed for certain states if their legislature does not convene regular sessions in fiscal years 2010 and 2011. Starting from the first applicable fiscal year, states failing to comply may face monetary penalties and community service as consequences. Starting from fiscal year 2012, states receiving grants under section 1921 must establish goals to reduce retailer violations of age prohibition laws. The violation rate should not exceed 20% in 2010, 19% in 2011, and 18% in 2012. Noncompliance may result in penalties and community service. In fiscal years 2010 to 2020, states must reduce retailer violations of age prohibition laws by decreasing violation rates annually from 20% to 10%. Enforcement measures are in place for noncompliance with grant funding agreements. In fiscal years 2010 to 2020, states must reduce retailer violations of age prohibition laws by decreasing violation rates annually from 20% to 10%. Enforcement measures are in place for noncompliance with grant funding agreements, ensuring states enforce laws to reduce availability of tobacco products to individuals under 18 years of age. States receiving grants under section 1921 must conduct annual unannounced inspections to ensure compliance with tobacco laws and submit reports detailing enforcement activities to the Secretary. The State must demonstrate enforcement of tobacco laws, success in meeting goals, and strategies for reducing availability of tobacco products to minors to qualify for a grant under section 1921. The State must enforce tobacco laws and demonstrate success in reducing availability of tobacco products to minors to qualify for a grant under section 1921. Individuals under 18 can be used in inspections with parental consent and direct state supervision. The State must enforce tobacco laws and show success in reducing tobacco availability to minors to be eligible for a grant under section 1921. Individuals under 18 can participate in inspections under direct state supervision. State settlement proceeds must be used as per the funding agreement for the grant. The Secretary must determine if a State has complied with tobacco laws before granting funds under section 1921. Noncompliance may result in a reduction of allotment starting from the first fiscal year. The Secretary may reduce a State's allotment under section 1921 if the State is found to be noncompliant with tobacco laws, starting from the first fiscal year. In fiscal years 2011, 2012, and beyond, the State's allotment under section 1933 will be reduced by 20%, 30%, and 40% respectively. In fiscal years 2011, 2012, and beyond, the State's allotment under section 1933 will be reduced by 20%, 30%, and 40% respectively. If the State is not in compliance with certain subsections, the Secretary may further reduce the allotment by 10%. The Secretary will reduce the State's allotment by 10% in addition to other reductions if not in compliance with certain subsections. The Secretary will provide assistance in developing and implementing State laws, including model legislative language and technical guidance. The term 'first applicable fiscal year' is defined in the section, with specific fiscal years assigned to different states. The amendment applies from the first applicable fiscal year onwards. The provisions of section 1926 of the Public Health Service Act apply to fiscal years preceding the first applicable fiscal year, with the term "first applicable fiscal year" defined in the subsection. SEC. 3. PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF INGREDIENTS. The Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act is amended to require the Secretary to make ingredient information accessible to the public online within 48 hours of receipt.
